revisions.rev:
[[Image:Scudetto.svg|right|thumb|150px|''Scudetto'']] The '''Italian football champions''' ({{lang-it|Scudetto}}, "little shield", plural: ''scudetti'') are the annual winners of [[Serie A]], [[Italy]]'s premier annual [[Football (soccer)|football]] league competition. The title has been contested since 1898 in varying forms of competition. While [[A.C. Milan|Milan]] are the current champions, [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]] have won a record 27 championship titles. The first time the ''Scudetto'' was used was in 1924 when [[Genoa C.F.C.|Genoa]] won its 9th championship title and decided to add a little shield to their shirt as to reward and celebrate themselves as champions. The finals of the first [[Italian Football Championship]] was decided in a single day with four teams competing, three from [[Turin]] and one from [[Genoa]]. The title was decided using a [[Single-elimination tournament|knock-out]] format between the finalists with [[Genoa C.F.C.|Genoa Cricket and Athletic Club]], the inaugural winners. The knock-out format was used until the [[Italian Football Championship 1909-10|1909â10]] season, when a league consisting of nine teams was formed. The regular league season was followed by a championship game featuring the first and second place teams. The championship, which had been confined to a single league in the north of Italy, became a national competition in 1929 with the foundation of [[Serie A]] and [[Serie B]]. Several times in history mark when a champion was not named. [[World War]]s suspended the official Championship from both 1915 to 1919 and 1943 to 1945, although unofficial championships were contested in both 1916 and 1944. Allegations of [[match fixing]] prevented a champion being declared in both the [[Italian Football Championship 1926-27|1926â27]] and [[Serie A 2004-05|2004â05 seasons]] with [[Torino F.C.|Torino Football Club]] and [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus Football Club]] being stripped of their titles, respectively. ==History== ===Italian Football Championship=== [[Image:Juventus FC in 1903.gif|right|thumb|[[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]], 1903 runners-up]] The first official national football tournament was organised in 1898 by the [[Italian Football Federation]] (Italian: ''Federazione Italiana Giuoco Calcio'', '''FIGC''').{{Cite web | url = http://www.figc.it/english/storia/storia_completa.htm#1898 | title = FIGC History â 1898 | accessdate = 2007-04-26 | publisher = FIGC }} This tournament, the final matches of the first [[Italian Football Championship]], were held in a single day on 8 May 1898 in [[Turin]]. [[Genoa C.F.C.|Genoa Cricket and Athletic Club]] were crowned as champions, defeating [[Internazionale Torino]] by 3â1, following extra time. In the following years, the tournament was structured into regional groups with the winners of each group participating in a playoff with the eventual winners being declared champions. The format was modified for the [[Italian Football Championship 1909-10|1909â10 season]] which was played in a league format. Nine clubs participated playing each other both home and away, and with the clubs finishing first and second playing for the championship in a single playoff final. This season was the first victory for [[F.C. Internazionale Milano|Football Club Internazionale Milano]], who defeated [[U.S. Pro Vercelli Calcio|Unione Sportiva Pro Vercelli Calcio]] in the final by a score of 10â3.{{Cite web | url = http://www.rsssf.com/tablesi/italhist98-25.html#10 | title = Italy â Championship History 1898â1923 | publisher = rsssf.com | accessdate = 2007-04-26 }} The [[Italian Football Championship 1912-13|1912â13]] season saw the competition nationalised with North and South divisions.{{Cite web | url = http://www.figc.it/english/storia/storia_completa.htm#1913 | title = FIGC History â 1913 | accessdate = 2007-04-26 | publisher = FIGC }} In 1916, [[A.C. Milan|Associazione Calcio Milan]] won the ''Coppa Federale'', which for that season was a substitute for the championship, which had been suspended because of [[World War I]].{{Cite web | url = http://www.rsssf.com/tablesj/juvemilan.html | title = Juventus vs Milan | publisher = rsssf.com | accessdate = 2007-04-26 }} The tournament that year was limited to clubs from the north, with the exception of Pro Vercelli, but was not treated as an official trophy or recognised by FIGC as an Italian title. Controversy hit the Championship in the 1921â22 season which saw the major clubs (including Pro Vercelli, [[Bologna F.C. 1909|Bologna]] and Juventus) in dispute with the FIGC. The teams had asked for a reduction in the number of clubs in the top division in accordance with a plan drawn up by [[Vittorio Pozzo]], the [[Italian national football team|Italian national team]] coach. Pozzo's plan was dismissed and the '''CCI''' (Italian: ''Confederazione Calcistica Italiana'') was founded and organised a [[Italian Football Championship 1921-22 (C.C.I.)|1921â22 CCI league]] to run concurrently with the [[Italian Football Championship 1921-22 (F.I.G.C.)|1921â22 season]] organised by the FIGC.{{Cite web | url = http://www.rsssf.com/tablesi/italchamp.html | title = Italy â List of Champions | accessdate = 2007-04-26 | publisher = rsssf.com }} Further scandal followed in the [[Italian Football Championship 1926-27|1926â27 season]] when title-winners [[Torino F.C.|Torino Football Club]] were stripped of their ''Scudetto'' following an FIGC investigation. A Torino official was found to have bribed opposing defender [[Luigi Allemandi]] in Torino's match against Juventus on 5 June 1927, and thus the season finished with no declared champions. {{Cite web | url = http://sport.independent.co.uk/football/internationals/article1166526.ece | title = Italy are fabulously flawed | author = James Lawton | publisher = [[The Independent]] | date = 2006-07-08 | accessdate = 2007-04-17 }} ===Serie A=== Following the scandal of match-fixing and the split between the FIGC and the CCI, the ''[[Viareggio]] charter'' was drawn up to legalise professionalism, ban foreign players, and rationalise the championship from its regionalised state into national leagues: the [[Serie A]] and [[Serie B]].{{Cite book | title = Calcio â a history of Italian Football | author = John Foot | ISBN = 0007175744 | publisher = Fourth Estate }} The [[Serie A 1929-30|1929â30 season]] was the inaugural Serie A season and was won by [[F.C. Internazionale Milano|Internazionale]] (called ''Ambrosiana'' at the time). The next 11 years were also dominated by [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]] and [[Bologna F.C. 1909|Bologna]], when all of the ''Scudetti'' were won between the three of them, Juventus winning five times in a row, a record only equalled by Internazionale in 2010. The competition was truncated as the Championship was suspended in 1943 due to [[World War II]]. A Championship was held in 1944, the [[Campionato Alta Italia 1944|Campionato Alta Italia]], and won by [[Spezia Calcio|Spezia]].{{Cite web | url = http://www.rsssf.com/tablesi/ital44.html | title = Italy 1943/44 (War Championship) | publisher = rsssf.com | accessdate = 2007-04-26 }} The title was not officially recognised by FIGC until 2002 and even then the ''Scudetto'' is considered a "decoration."{{Cite web | url = http://www.acspezia1906.it/LaStoria/lo_scudetto_del_44_4p.asp | language = Italian | publisher = Spezia Calcio 1906 | accessdate = 2007-04-26 | title = Lo scudetto del '44 â 4a parte }} The post-war years were dominated by [[Torino F.C.|Torino]] (then called ''The Great Torino''), a team which found a dramatic end in the [[Superga]] air disaster in 1949. The 1950s saw the gradual emergence of [[A.C. Milan|Milan]], with the help of [[Sweden|Swedish]] striker [[Gunnar Nordahl]], who was Serie A's leading scorer (Italian: ''Capocannonieri'') for five out of six seasons. [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]] began to dominate throughout the 1970s and early 1980s with nine ''Scudetti'' in fifteen seasons while the 1990s saw Milan come to prominence. Serie A was dealt another blow by the [[2006 Italian football scandal]] which involved alleged widespread match fixing implicating league champions [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]], and other major teams including [[A.C. Milan|Milan]], [[ACF Fiorentina|Fiorentina]], [[S.S. Lazio|Lazio]], and [[Reggina Calcio|Reggina]].{{Cite web | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/europe/4993482.stm | title = Serie A quartet will stand trial | publisher = [[BBC Sport]] | date = 2006-06-23 | accessdate = 2007-04-26 }} The FIGC ruled Juventus be stripped of their title, relegated to [[Serie B]] and start the following season with a nine-point deduction. The other clubs involved suffered similarly with relegation and points deduction.{{Cite web | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/europe/5164194.stm | title = Italian trio relegated to Serie B | publisher = [[BBC Sport]] | date = 2006-07-14 | accessdate = 2007-04-26 }} ==Winners== ===Italian Football Championship=== {| class="wikitable" width=80%; !width=8%|Year !width=20%|Winner !width=20%|Runners-up !width=20%|Third Place !width=35%|Top scorer (club) (goals) |- | [[1898 Italian Football Championship|1898]] || [[Genoa C.F.C.|Genoa]] (1) || Internazionale Torino || (Unknown) || (Unknown) |- | [[1899 Italian Football Championship|1899]] || Genoa (2) || Internazionale Torino || Ginnastica Torino || (Unknown) |- | [[1900 Italian Football Championship|1900]] || Genoa (3) || Torinese || Milan || (Unknown) |- | [[1901 Italian Football Championship|1901]] || [[A.C.
